headline: Tesla's Chinese Rival Geely Mulling US Market Debut In The Next 2-3 Years: Report
summary: Chinese automaker Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd. (OTC:GELYF) (OTC:GELHY) is reportedly mulling an entry into the U.S. market in the near future. Debut In The Next 2-3 Years Ash Sutcliffe, Geely's Head of Global Communications, spoke at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2026 and shared that the automaker could make "an announcement on that in the next 24-36 months," Autoline reported on Monday in a video on YouTube. Geely didn’t immediately respond to Benzinga‘s request for comment. Don't Miss:

headline: Elon Musk Says Tesla's Planned $10B Spend On Nvidia Hardware Would Be Double If Not For This Reason, Laments Lack Of AI Investments In Auto Industry
summary: Tesla Inc. (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk stated on Monday that the EV maker would have had to spend twice as much on buying AI hardware from Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) to train its systems if it weren’t for the company’s AI4 chipset. Musk Touts $10 Billion Nvidia Spending Musk also shared that Tesla was making close to two million cars annually and growing, all of which boast Tesla's "dual SoC AI4, 8 cameras, redundancy in steering actuation and others systems, high bandwidth communication, etc."

content.title: Elon Musk Says Tesla's Planned $10B Spend On Nvidia Hardware Would Be Double If Not For This Reason, Laments Lack Of AI Investments In Auto Industry
content.summary: Tesla Inc. (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk stated on Monday that the EV maker would have had to spend twice as much on buying AI hardware from Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) to train its systems if it weren’t for the company’s AI4 chipset. Musk Touts $10 Billion Nvidia Spending Musk also shared that Tesla was making close to two million cars annually and growing, all of which boast Tesla's "dual SoC AI4, 8 cameras, redundancy in steering actuation and others systems, high bandwidth communication, etc."

headline: SanDisk Trending After Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang Flags Memory As Major 'Unserved Market' With Surging Demand And Prices
summary: Shares of storage solutions company, SanDisk Corp. (NASDAQ:SNDK) rallied 27.56% on Tuesday, becoming the best performer in the S&P 500 for the day, following Nvidia Corp. (NASDAQ:NVDA) CEO Jensen Huang’s remarks on the growing importance of the storage market. headline: Japan's Record Bond Yields Put Yen Carry Trade Back in Focus: Could This Spark Fresh Trouble For US Markets?
summary: Japan’s 30-year treasury yields touched their highest level on record, at 3.52% on Tuesday night, a 48-basis-point increase since November, sparking concerns of potential fallout across the U.S. and global markets. Deteriorating Fiscal Conditions Push Yields Higher After decades of serving as the world’s low-yield anchor, with negative short-term interest rates, Japan’s government bond yields have surged significantly over the past year. This comes as concerns mount over Japan's fiscal trajector

headline: GM to take $6 billion EV-related charge
summary: Shortly after the market closed on Thursday, General Motors (GM) revealed it is taking an additional $6 billion charge to its EV business. Yahoo Finance Senior Autos Reporter Pras Subramanian reports the details. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: GM to take $7.1B hit from electric vehicle production changes, China restructuring
summary: GM said in a Form 8-K filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that the charge will impact fourth-quarter 2025 earnings.

content.title: GM to take $7.1B hit from electric vehicle production changes, China restructuring
content.summary: GM said in a Form 8-K filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that the charge will impact fourth-quarter 2025 earnings.

headline: GM Takes Another EV Charge—and Warns It Won’t Be the Last
summary: GM is essentially writing down assets that already exist on the books, and $4.2 billion in cash settlements, reflecting lower-than-contracted volumes with suppliers.  GM isn’t done either.  “We expect to recognize additional material cash and non-cash charges in 2026 related to continued commercial negotiations with our supply base, which we believe will be significantly less than the EV-related charges incurred in 2025,” GM added.

content.title: GM Takes Another EV Charge—and Warns It Won’t Be the Last
content.summary: GM is essentially writing down assets that already exist on the books, and $4.2 billion in cash settlements, reflecting lower-than-contracted volumes with suppliers.  GM isn’t done either.  “We expect to recognize additional material cash and non-cash charges in 2026 related to continued commercial negotiations with our supply base, which we believe will be significantly less than the EV-related charges incurred in 2025,” GM added.

headline: General Motors to Report $6B Charge From Electric Vehicle Review
summary: General Motors expects to incur a $6 billion charge in the fourth quarter from a review of its electric vehicle manufacturing capacity following the end of a $7,500 EV tax credit and slowing consumer demand.

content.title: General Motors to Report $6B Charge From Electric Vehicle Review
content.summary: General Motors expects to incur a $6 billion charge in the fourth quarter from a review of its electric vehicle manufacturing capacity following the end of a $7,500 EV tax credit and slowing consumer demand.

headline: GM Takes $6 Billion Hit Tied to Electric Vehicles as Demand Sinks
summary: General Motors  said it would book a $6 billion charge on its fast-shrinking, money-losing electric-vehicle business, the latest reckoning tied to the collapse of EVs in the U.S.  GM said the charges reflected moves to shrink EV capacity amid slower demand for the vehicles following moves in Washington to end policies that helped spur demand.  GM shares were down 2% in after-hours trading on the news.

content.title: GM Takes $6 Billion Hit Tied to Electric Vehicles as Demand Sinks
content.summary: General Motors  said it would book a $6 billion charge on its fast-shrinking, money-losing electric-vehicle business, the latest reckoning tied to the collapse of EVs in the U.S.  GM said the charges reflected moves to shrink EV capacity amid slower demand for the vehicles following moves in Washington to end policies that helped spur demand.  GM shares were down 2% in after-hours trading on the news.

headline: Polymarket Traders Fume As Prediction Platform Refuses To Settle Bets Worth Over $10 Million On US Invasion Of Venezuela— 'You Cannot Change Rules…'
summary: Prediction platform Polymarket is facing backlash after refusing to settle contracts betting on whether the U.S. would “invade” Venezuela, following a special forces operation that led to the capture of Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro on Saturday. Bets worth around $10.7 million are currently tied up in the disputed contracts, leaving bettors furious and reigniting questions around transparency and governance in the largely unregulated prediction market industry. Polymarket Says Raid Doesn’t Me

headline: GM stock falls 2% after $6B EV-related charges announced
summary: Investing.com -- General Motors (NYSE: GM) stock fell 2% in after-hours trading Thursday following the automaker’s disclosure of approximately $6 billion in fourth-quarter charges primarily related to its electric vehicle operations in North America.

content.title: GM stock falls 2% after $6B EV-related charges announced
content.summary: Investing.com -- General Motors (NYSE: GM) stock fell 2% in after-hours trading Thursday following the automaker’s disclosure of approximately $6 billion in fourth-quarter charges primarily related to its electric vehicle operations in North America.

headline: GM takes $6 billion hit as cost of backing away from EVs
summary: General Motors on Thursday said it will take an additional $6 billion hit against its earnings as result of it pulling back on its electric vehicle plans.

content.title: GM takes $6 billion hit as cost of backing away from EVs
content.summary: General Motors on Thursday said it will take an additional $6 billion hit against its earnings as result of it pulling back on its electric vehicle plans.

thumbnail.caption: GMC Hummer electric vehicles on the production line at General Motors' Factory Zero in Detroit. GM is taking a $6 billion charge as it pulls back on its electric vehicle plans. - Emily Elconin/Bloomberg/Getty Images
